The Bochner integral in L1 space

type:
{Î± : Type u_5} â†’

name: MeasureTheory.L1.integral
docString: The Bochner integral in L1 space

For any integrable function `f` from a box `I` to the normed space `E` over real numbers, with respect to a normed additive group `Î¹`, a finite type instance for `Î¹`, a normed space `F`, an integration parameter `l`, and a box additive map `vol` from `Î¹` to `E â†’â„[â„] F`, the integral of `f` over `I` with respect to `vol` and `l` exists and equals the box integral of `f` over `I` with respect to `vol` and `l`.

type:
âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E]
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„ F] {I : BoxIntegral.Box Î¹} [inst_4 : Fintype Î¹]
  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {f : (Î¹ â†’ â„) â†’ E} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Î¹ (E â†’L[â„] F) âŠ¤},
  BoxIntegral.Integrable I l f vol â†’ BoxIntegral.HasIntegral I l f vol (BoxIntegral.integral I l f vol)
name: BoxIntegral.Integrable.hasIntegral
docString: For any integrable function `f` from a box `I` to the normed space `E` over real numbers, with respect to a normed additive group `Î¹`, a finite type instance for `Î¹`, a normed space `F`, an integration parameter `l`, and a box additive map `vol` from `Î¹` to `E â†’â„[â„] F`, the integral of `f` over `I` with respect to `vol` and `l` exists and equals the box integral of `f` over `I` with respect to `vol` and `l`.

This theorem states that for any given type `Î¹`, and any given normed add commutative groups `E` and `F` over the real numbers with `E` and `F` also being a normed space over the real numbers. If `I` is a box integral (a multi-dimensional generalization of an interval), `l` is some integration parameters, `vol` is a box additive map (linear maps that preserve addition) between `Î¹` and the continuous linear mappings from `E` to `F`, and `c` is an element of `E`, then the integral of the constant function `c` over the box `I` with respect to `vol` is equal to `vol` applied to `I` and `c`. In other words, the integral of a constant function over a box integral is simply the volume of the box times the constant.

type:
âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E]
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„ F] {I : BoxIntegral.Box Î¹} [inst_4 : Fintype Î¹]
  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Î¹ (E â†’L[â„] F) âŠ¤} (c : E),
  BoxIntegral.HasIntegral I l (fun x => c) vol ((vol I) c)
name: BoxIntegral.hasIntegral_const
docString: This theorem states that for any given type `Î¹`, and any given normed add commutative groups `E` and `F` over the real numbers with `E` and `F` also being a normed space over the real numbers. If `I` is a box integral (a multi-dimensional generalization of an interval), `l` is some integration parameters, `vol` is a box additive map (linear maps that preserve addition) between `Î¹` and the continuous linear mappings from `E` to `F`, and `c` is an element of `E`, then the integral of the constant function `c` over the box `I` with respect to `vol` is equal to `vol` applied to `I` and `c`. In other words, the integral of a constant function over a box integral is simply the volume of the box times the constant.

The Fourier integral of an `L^1` function is a continuous function.

  [inst_10 : TopologicalSpace V] [inst_11 : BorelSpace V] [inst_12 : TopologicalSpace W]
  {e : Multiplicative ğ•œ â†’* â†¥circle} {Î¼ : MeasureTheory.Measure V} {L : V â†’â‚—[ğ•œ] W â†’â‚—[ğ•œ] ğ•œ}
  [inst_13 : FirstCountableTopology W],
  Continuous â‡‘e â†’

name: VectorFourier.fourierIntegral_continuous
docString: The Fourier integral of an `L^1` function is a continuous function.

For a given normed add commutative group `E`, normed space `F` over `â„`, box `I`, integration parameter `l`, function `f` from `Î¹` to `â„`, volume function `vol`, and target value `y`, `f` has an integral over box `I` with parameters `l` and volume `vol` equal to `y` if and only if for every `Îµ > 0`, there exists a function `r` such that for all `c > 0` and tagged prepartitions `Ï€` of `I` that are a base set, partition, and satisfy `l.RCond (r c)`, the integral sum of `f` over `Ï€` with volume `vol` is within `Îµ` of `y`.

type:
âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E]
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„ F] {I : BoxIntegral.Box Î¹} [inst_4 : Fintype Î¹]
  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {f : (Î¹ â†’ â„) â†’ E} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Î¹ (E â†’L[â„] F) âŠ¤} {y : F},
  BoxIntegral.HasIntegral I l f vol y â†”
    âˆ€ Îµ > 0,
      âˆƒ r,
        (âˆ€ (c : NNReal), l.RCond (r c)) âˆ§
          âˆ€ (c : NNReal) (Ï€ : BoxIntegral.TaggedPrepartition I),
            l.MemBaseSet I c (r c) Ï€ â†’ Ï€.IsPartition â†’ dist (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol Ï€) y â‰¤ Îµ
name: BoxIntegral.hasIntegral_iff
docString: For a given normed add commutative group `E`, normed space `F` over `â„`, box `I`, integration parameter `l`, function `f` from `Î¹` to `â„`, volume function `vol`, and target value `y`, `f` has an integral over box `I` with parameters `l` and volume `vol` equal to `y` if and only if for every `Îµ > 0`, there exists a function `r` such that for all `c > 0` and tagged prepartitions `Ï€` of `I` that are a base set, partition, and satisfy `l.RCond (r c)`, the integral sum of `f` over `Ï€` with volume `vol` is within `Îµ` of `y`.

This theorem states that for any function `f` from a real-valued vector to a normed add-commutative group `E` and any `vol` (which is a box-additive map from `Î¹` to the continuous linear map from `E` to a normed add-commutative group `F`), if `f` has an integral over a given box `I` according to a set of integration parameters `l`, that yields an element `y` of `F`, then `f` is integrable over box `I` with respect to the volume element `vol` and the integration parameters `l`. This holds for any given types `Î¹`, `E`, `F` and for any `I`, `l`, `f`, `vol`, `y` which satisfy the conditions described.

  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {f : (Î¹ â†’ â„) â†’ E} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Î¹ (E â†’L[â„] F) âŠ¤} {y : F},
  BoxIntegral.HasIntegral I l f vol y â†’ BoxIntegral.Integrable I l f vol
name: BoxIntegral.HasIntegral.integrable
docString: This theorem states that for any function `f` from a real-valued vector to a normed add-commutative group `E` and any `vol` (which is a box-additive map from `Î¹` to the continuous linear map from `E` to a normed add-commutative group `F`), if `f` has an integral over a given box `I` according to a set of integration parameters `l`, that yields an element `y` of `F`, then `f` is integrable over box `I` with respect to the volume element `vol` and the integration parameters `l`. This holds for any given types `Î¹`, `E`, `F` and for any `I`, `l`, `f`, `vol`, `y` which satisfy the conditions described.
